text:
quick DataFrame question: I am trying to read CSVs that, for some reason, have possibly many columns of missing data at the end. The columns are entirely missing.

Is there something similar to dropmissing that operates on columns?

elements.text:
quick DataFrame question: I am trying to read CSVs that, for some reason, have possibly many columns of missing data at the end. The columns are entirely missing.

Is there something similar to dropmissing that operates on columns?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/55404| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
Extremely hard to google a nice approach to this. DataFrames documentation gives extremely verbose descriptions of how to drop rows with missing entries

elements.text: Extremely hard to google a nice approach to this. DataFrames documentation gives extremely verbose descriptions of how to drop rows with missing entries

text:
Consider the following data in a file called `data.csv`
```foo,bar,baz
a,,2
b,,2
c,,
,,4
e,,5```
You could check the type of each column:
```using CSV
import DataFrames: DataFrame
import SentinelArrays: MissingVector

csv_file = "data.csv"
df = CSV.read(csv_file, DataFrame)

df[:, .!isa.(eachcol(df), MissingVector)]```
